chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected renal or ureteric colic?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Take a history. 
    • Ask about symptoms experienced, including the duration, severity, and any exacerbating or relieving factors. 
      • Renal or ureteric colic is characterized by an abrupt onset of severe unilateral abdominal pain originating in the loin or flank and radiating to the labia in women or to the groin or testicle in men.
      • The pain typically lasts minutes to hours and occurs in spasms (with intervals of no pain or dull ache). The pain is often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and haematuria, and is usually described as the most severe pain experienced by the person — many women describe it as being more intense than the pain of childbirth.
      • The person may complain of dysuria, urinary frequency, and straining (due to the stone irritating the detrusor muscle when it reaches the vesico-ureteric junction).
    • Review the person's medical, drug, and family history as well as their dietary habits to identify risk factors for stone formation. The person may have a history of previous episodes.
  • Examine the person.
    • Perform a full and thorough abdominal examination to help exclude differential diagnoses, such as ruptured aortic aneurysm, appendicitis, diverticulitis, and peritonitis.
      • The person may be restless and unable to lie still (which helps to differentiate renal colic from peritonitis).
    • Look for signs which may indicate a complication, such as:
      • Hesitancy of micturition or an intermittent urinary stream — suggesting urinary tract obstruction.
      • Fever and sweats — suggesting coexisting urinary tract infection.
  • Consider urine dipstick testing to support the diagnosis and to exclude infection.
    • Check for haematuria — the presence of haematuria can support the diagnosis of renal or ureteric colic. However, specificity and positive predictive values are poor, and the absence of haematuria does not exclude a diagnosis but should prompt consideration for other causes of pain.
    • Check for nitrite and leucocyte esterase — the presence of nitrite (with or without leucocyte esterase) in the urine suggests a urinary tract infection. See the CKS topics on Urinary tract infection (lower) - men and Urinary tract infection (lower) - women for more information.
  • If there is suspicion for urinary stones based on the history, physical examination, and investigations, see the section on Management for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the guideline Urolithiasis published by the European Association of Urology (EAU) [EAU, 2018], the British Association of Urological Surgeons standards for management of acute ureteric colic published by the British Association of Urological Surgeons (BAUS) [Tsiotras, 2017], Urolithiasis: evaluation, dietary factors, and medical management: an update of the 2014 SIU-ICUD international consultation on stone disease published by the Société Internationale d’Urologie (SIU) and the International Consultation on Urologic Diseases (ICUD) [Jung, 2017], and on expert opinion in review articles [Portis and Sundaram, 2001; Stewart and Joyce, 2008; Bultitude and Rees, 2012; Manjunath et al, 2013; BPAC NZ, 2014; Morgan, 2016; BMJ, 2018] and the Oxford Textbook of Medicine [Worcester et al, 2010].

History

  • The recommendation to take a thorough history is based on the SIU/ICUD guideline [Jung, 2017] and on expert opinion in a review article [Morgan, 2016].
    • A thorough patient history may provide key information and influence further management and treatment [Jung, 2017].

Examination

  • Several conditions can cause acute abdominal pain, for example, ruptured aortic aneurysm and diverticulitis. It is important that these conditions are excluded in people who present with abdominal pain [Bultitude and Rees, 2012; Manjunath et al, 2013; BPAC NZ, 2014].
  • Signs which may indicate a complication should be identified so that the person can be properly managed [Stewart and Joyce, 2008; Bultitude and Rees, 2012; BPAC NZ, 2014; EAU, 2018].
  • Signs of sepsis, including fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, might indicate an obstructing stone with infection, which warrants urgent urology referral [BMJ, 2018].

Considering urine dipstick testing

  • Although laboratory investigations are usually done in secondary care for people with suspected renal or ureteric colic, CKS recommends considering urine dipstick testing as part of the inital assessment to support the diagnosis and exclude infection. 
  • Initial laboratory investigations for people with suspected renal or ureteric stones include [Tsiotras, 2017; BMJ, 2018; EAU, 2018]:
    • Urine dipstix (to test for microscopic haematuria).
    • Urine microscopy, culture, and sensitivity (to test for blood, pus cells, and evidence of infection).
    • Serum urea, creatinine, and electrolytes, including estimated glomerular filtration rate (to assess renal funtion).
